segment.source: Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM
segment.target: Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM

segment.source: Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM
segment.target: Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM

segment.source: Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM
segment.target: Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM

segment.source: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to mount a Windows image from a WIM or VHD file.
segment.target: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to mount a Windows image from a WIM or VHD file.

segment.source: Mounting an image maps the contents of the image to a directory so that you can service the image using DISM without booting into the image.
segment.target: Mounting an image maps the contents of the image to a directory so that you can service the image using DISM without booting into the image.

segment.source: You can also perform common file operations, such as copying, pasting, and editing on a mounted image.
segment.target: You can also perform common file operations, such as copying, pasting, and editing on a mounted image.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: DISM cannot mount a Windows image from a VHD on Windows Vista with Service Pack 1 (SP1) or Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: DISM cannot mount a Windows image from a VHD on Windows Vista with Service Pack 1 (SP1) or Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: You must attach the VHD using the DiskPart tool before you can use DISM to service the image.
segment.target: You must attach the VHD using the DiskPart tool before you can use DISM to service the image.

segment.source: When you service VHD images that have been attached using the DiskPart tool, the changes are automatically committed with each operation and cannot be discarded.
segment.target: When you service VHD images that have been attached using the DiskPart tool, the changes are automatically committed with each operation and cannot be discarded.

segment.source: You can mount and modify multiple images on a single computer.
segment.target: You can mount and modify multiple images on a single computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) Best Practices.
segment.target: For more information, see Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) Best Practices.

segment.source: Mounting an Image
segment.target: Mounting an Image

segment.source: You can mount an image using the /optimize option to reduce initial mount time.
segment.target: You can mount an image using the /optimize option to reduce initial mount time.

segment.source: However, When using the /optimize option, processes that are ordinarily performed during a mount will instead be completed the first time that you access a directory.
segment.target: However, When using the /optimize option, processes that are ordinarily performed during a mount will instead be completed the first time that you access a directory.

segment.source: As a result, there may be an increase in the time that is required to access a directory for the first time after mounting an image using the /optimize option.
segment.target: As a result, there may be an increase in the time that is required to access a directory for the first time after mounting an image using the /optimize option.

segment.source: To mount an image
segment.target: To mount an image

segment.source: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.
segment.target: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.

segment.source: If you are using a version of Windows other than Windows 8, use the Deployment Tools Cmd Prompt installed with the ADK or navigate to the DISM directory on your local computer.
segment.target: If you are using a version of Windows other than Windows 8, use the Deployment Tools Cmd Prompt installed with the ADK or navigate to the DISM directory on your local computer.

segment.source: Mount the image.
segment.target: Mount the image.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To mount a Windows image from a VHD file, you must specify .
segment.target: To mount a Windows image from a VHD file, you must specify .

segment.source: You can also add options to mount the image with read-only permissions or to reduce the initial mount time with the /Optimize option.
segment.target: You can also add options to mount the image with read-only permissions or to reduce the initial mount time with the /Optimize option.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: For more information about the options available for the /Mount-Image option in DISM, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about the options available for the /Mount-Image option in DISM, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Modifying an Image
segment.target: Modifying an Image

segment.source: After you mount an image, you can browse the directory of the image.
segment.target: After you mount an image, you can browse the directory of the image.

segment.source: You can review the file and folder structure, and add, edit, or delete files and folders.
segment.target: You can review the file and folder structure, and add, edit, or delete files and folders.

segment.source: You can also use the DISM tool to add and remove drivers and packages, including language packs, enumerate drivers and packages, modify configuration settings, and more.
segment.target: You can also use the DISM tool to add and remove drivers and packages, including language packs, enumerate drivers and packages, modify configuration settings, and more.

segment.source: For more information, see Service a Windows Image Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Service a Windows Image Using DISM.

segment.source: To view and modify an image
segment.target: To view and modify an image

segment.source: On your technician computer open the mounted directory.
segment.target: On your technician computer open the mounted directory.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Delete, edit, or add additional files and folders to the location where they must appear after they have been applied to the destination computer.
segment.target: Delete, edit, or add additional files and folders to the location where they must appear after they have been applied to the destination computer.

segment.source: For example, C:programfilesapplicationname.
segment.target: For example, C:programfilesapplicationname.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: If you must add an application or a device, verify that you included all of the required files.
segment.target: If you must add an application or a device, verify that you included all of the required files.

segment.source: Although you can add application files and folders, you cannot install applications.
segment.target: Although you can add application files and folders, you cannot install applications.

segment.source: Committing Changes to an Image
segment.target: Committing Changes to an Image

segment.source: You can commit changes to an image without unmounting the image.
segment.target: You can commit changes to an image without unmounting the image.

segment.source: To commit changes to an image
segment.target: To commit changes to an image

segment.source: At the command prompt, type:
segment.target: At the command prompt, type:

segment.source: Use /CheckIntegrity to detect and track .wim file corruption when you commit changes to the image.
segment.target: Use /CheckIntegrity to detect and track .wim file corruption when you commit changes to the image.

segment.source: When you apply or mount the image, use /CheckIntegrity again to stop the operation if file corruption was detected.
segment.target: When you apply or mount the image, use /CheckIntegrity again to stop the operation if file corruption was detected.

segment.source: /CheckIntegrity cannot be used with virtual hard disk (VHD) files.
segment.target: /CheckIntegrity cannot be used with virtual hard disk (VHD) files.

segment.source: Unmounting an Image
segment.target: Unmounting an Image

segment.source: After you modify an image, you must unmount it.
segment.target: After you modify an image, you must unmount it.

segment.source: If you mounted your image with the default read/write permissions, you can commit your changes.
segment.target: If you mounted your image with the default read/write permissions, you can commit your changes.

segment.source: This makes your modifications a permanent part of the image.
segment.target: This makes your modifications a permanent part of the image.

segment.source: To unmount an image
segment.target: To unmount an image

segment.source: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.
segment.target: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.

segment.source: If you are using a version of Windows other than Windows 8, use the Deployment Tools Cmd Prompt installed with the ADK or navigate to the DISM directory on your local computer.
segment.target: If you are using a version of Windows other than Windows 8, use the Deployment Tools Cmd Prompt installed with the ADK or navigate to the DISM directory on your local computer.

segment.source: For Windows 10:
segment.target: For Windows 10:

segment.source: where architecture can be x86 or amd64.
segment.target: where architecture can be x86 or amd64.

segment.source: Unmount the image.
segment.target: Unmount the image.

segment.source: where is the location of the mount directory.
segment.target: where is the location of the mount directory.

segment.source: If you do not specify the parameters to unmount, this option lists all of the mounted images but does not perform the unmount action.
segment.target: If you do not specify the parameters to unmount, this option lists all of the mounted images but does not perform the unmount action.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You must use either the /commit or /discard argument when you use the /unmount option.
segment.target: You must use either the /commit or /discard argument when you use the /unmount option.

segment.source: After modifying an image, you can apply the image from a network share or from local media, such as a CD/DVD or a USB flash drive (UFD).
segment.target: After modifying an image, you can apply the image from a network share or from local media, such as a CD/DVD or a USB flash drive (UFD).

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: If the DISM commands in this topic fail, try the following:
segment.target: If the DISM commands in this topic fail, try the following:

segment.source: Make sure that you are using the Windows 10 version of DISM that is installed with the Windows ADK.
segment.target: Make sure that you are using the Windows 10 version of DISM that is installed with the Windows ADK.

segment.source: If you are using a Windows 8.1, Windows 8, or Windows 7 PC, use the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment to access the tools that are installed with the Windows 10 version of the Windows ADK.
segment.target: If you are using a Windows 8.1, Windows 8, or Windows 7 PC, use the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment to access the tools that are installed with the Windows 10 version of the Windows ADK.

segment.source: Don’t mount images to protected folders, such as your UserDocuments folder.
segment.target: Don’t mount images to protected folders, such as your UserDocuments folder.

segment.source: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider temporarily disconnecting from the network and disabling virus protection.
segment.target: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider temporarily disconnecting from the network and disabling virus protection.

segment.source: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider running the commands from the Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) instead.
segment.target: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider running the commands from the Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) instead.
